body: Linux' own `touch` command clears contents of the file. Is this intentional?

Linux' own `touch` command should not clear the contents, only update the file's last access and modification time or creates a new file if it doesn't exist as @ncw suggests.

What is the spec of such a feature and what is the use case?  Would this feature re-create a file/folder structure in a remote location (full of empty files)?

> What is the spec of such a feature and what is the use case? 

An easy way to create an empty file, or update the modtime of a file

> Would this feature re-create a file/folder structure in a remote location (full of empty files)?

Yes it would (that is how rclone works in general).

Hi,
I would like to work with this issue.

Hi,
I have implemented basic functionality and I am working on flags.
On macOS (on linux most likely too) when we try create file in folder that doesn't exists command returns error

Ex.
$ touch dirA/fileB
"touch: dirA/fileB: No such file or directory"

The better way is return any error (which one will the most appropriate?) or create missing dir?

@kubatasiemski Good work.
Yes I suggest that the default implementation recreates the folder structure.
@kubatasiemski how are you doing with this?  Are you ready to send a PR?
I have been very busy with study this week. I will send PR tomorrow. Now I have touch command and most of the flags. I have to create documentation and unit tests.

issue.title: Issue 1594 touch

repository.name: rclone
repository.description: "rsync for cloud storage" - Google Drive, S3, Dropbox, Backblaze B2, One Drive, Swift, Hubic, Wasabi, Google Cloud Storage, Azure Blob, Azure Files, Yandex Files

issue.body:
I implemented touch command with two flags (-C and -t).
I also add simple tests.
